metadata.title: Convert Megabits per Second to Megabytes per Second
metadata.description: Quick, authoritative conversion between megabits per second (Mbps) and megabytes per second (MB/s). Includes method notes for decimal vs binary definitions, practical caveats for network throughput, and references to standards for unit usage.

introduction: This tool converts a data transfer rate expressed in megabits per second (Mbps) to megabytes per second (MB/s). It is intended for quick unit conversions used in networking, bandwidth planning, and file transfer time estimates.

Bits and bytes are different units: 1 byte = 8 bits. Many networking speeds are quoted in bits per second while file sizes are commonly expressed in bytes, so converting between Mbps and MB/s is a frequent practical need. This converter assumes the conventional definitions described below but highlights decimal versus binary distinctions and protocol overhead that affect real-world throughput.
methodology: Conversion uses the fixed mathematical relationship between bits and bytes: 8 bits = 1 byte. The primary conversion is therefore exact: MB/s = Mbps ÷ 8, when both units use decimal prefixes.

Standards and nomenclature: this page follows international guidance on unit presentation and prefixes. When greater precision is required, consider whether the measurement uses decimal SI prefixes (mega = 10^6) or binary prefixes (mebi = 2^20). Also account for network and protocol overhead; the theoretical conversion does not include packet headers, retransmissions, or application-layer framing.

Accuracy caveats: reported link rates (e.g., an ISP's advertised Mbps) are link-layer or PHY rates and do not guarantee sustained application-layer MB/s. For regulatory and presentation guidance, consult national metrology and standards organizations.
how_is_calculated: Decimal megabit/megabyte conversion (common): MB/s = Mbps ÷ 8. Example: 100 Mbps = 100 ÷ 8 = 12.5 MB/s.
If source uses binary megabytes (mebibyte): MiB/s = (Mbps ÷ 8) × (10^6 ÷ 2^20) ≈ (Mbps ÷ 8) × 0.953674. Adjust if your source explicitly uses MiB.
Remember: multiply or divide only after confirming whether units are decimal (MB = 10^6 bytes) or binary (MiB = 2^20 bytes).
examples: 100 Mbps using MiB: 100 ÷ 8 = 12.5 decimal MB/s; in MiB/s ≈ 12.5 × 0.953674 = 11.921 MiB/s

faqs.question: Is MB/s the same as MBps or MBps vs Mbps?
faqs.answer: MB/s and MBps are commonly used to mean megabytes per second (bytes per second). Mbps (lowercase b) means megabits per second (bits per second). The key difference is a factor of 8: 1 byte = 8 bits.

faqs.question: Why does my 100 Mbps connection not give 12.5 MB/s file downloads?
faqs.answer: Real-world transfers are affected by protocol overhead, encryption, server or disk limits, congestion, and measurement methodology. Advertised link speed is a peak physical-layer rate; application-layer throughput is usually lower.

faqs.question: Should I use MB (decimal) or MiB (binary) in calculations?
faqs.answer: Use decimal MB (10^6 bytes) when the source explicitly states MB or when using most networking or storage vendor specifications. Use MiB (2^20 bytes) only when a tool or dataset explicitly uses binary prefixes. Always confirm the unit definition in your data source.

faqs.question: Does this converter include overheads like TCP/IP headers?
faqs.answer: No. This converter performs a pure unit conversion between bits and bytes. It does not account for protocol headers, encapsulation, retransmissions, or other real-world overheads. For throughput planning, include an overhead margin appropriate to your protocol and environment.

faqs.question: How do I convert MB/s back to Mbps?
faqs.answer: Multiply by 8. Mbps = MB/s × 8 (assuming both use the same prefix definition: decimal or binary).

glossary.definition: The basic unit of information in computing and digital communications, represented as 0 or 1.
A group of 8 bits. Common unit for file sizes and memory capacity.
Megabits per second. A rate equal to one million bits per second when using decimal prefixes.
Megabytes per second. Typically means one million bytes per second when using decimal prefixes.
Mebibyte, a binary prefix unit equal to 2^20 bytes (1,048,576 bytes).
